title: RAW converted NTFS USB Hard Drive

forumNotes.author: scifi
forumNotes.content:
Hi, I've a problem. This will be the second time this has happened but not to the same USB hard drive. The drive changed to RAW and of course all my files are unavaliable. I'm wondering if I can repair the boot sector. On the other HD I used Easus Data Recovery Wizard. I was able to recover all my video fies BUT all my eComics and docs where saved in a subfolder labeled RAW. They were scrambled and unusable. If I could repair the boot sector I'm thinkin' I could save all those files.  

Would TestDisk do it? Or do I risk losing all my video files as well. It's a 2 Terabyte HD with 1 partition.  

scifi

forumNotes.author: scifi
forumNotes.content: Hi u2o. chkdsk states "The drive, the path, the file name is not valid". If I try changing from C: to I: (the drive in question) in a DOS box, "The file or directory is corrupted and unreadable"

forumNotes.author: u2o
forumNotes.content:
The problem now is very difficult. If you touch ~~the boot sector~~ , or rather the **MBR** , and it does badly, you can not recover anything after.  

Then I suggest you try some few applications (and need time to a disk that big). Try...  
Recuva  
TestDisk and PhotoRec  
R-Linux  
Glary Undelete  
NTFS Undelete  
Restoration  
etc ...  
There are several more applications, free and paid ... But not all work with the same mode and not all may recover any data type ...  

Also you should keep in mind that if the unit was very fragmented, the files are scattered across the disk, making it more difficult recovery ...  

You need time, time and patience  

Good luck! and would be grateful that you discuss your results

forumNotes.author: scifi
forumNotes.content: u2o, you suggested a reply to the solving of my RAW problem: I utilized Easeus Data Recovery 5.5.1 as I had previously on the first RAW converted HD. I decided that it would take even longer to image the HD (plus freeing up an additional 2T HD) so I tried saving the results differenty than I did with the 1st drive that I'd used Easeus on. If one uses this program DON'T attempt to pick out individual extensons (such as .doc or .jpg. JUST RECOVER EVERYTHING! It took just as long (24 hrs) to recover the HD but I recovered the .cbz and .cbr files as well as most everything else (mostly video files). I had attempted to save specific types and the program scrambled the files that didn't fit into those narrow parameters.
